article_title: Payer-Provider Consolidation Comes With New Risks
article_text:
Payer-Provider Consolidation Comes With New Risks

Law360, New York (January 15, 2015, 10:17 AM ET) -- The Affordable Care Act is accelerating change away from the fee-for-service health care delivery model by directing cost-reduction reforms at health care delivery. But any change in the way health care is delivered will necessarily implicate how it is paid for, which in turn implicates insurance coverage.



These strong economic forces coupled with the anxiety of payers and providers fearing they will be left behind is resulting in a more encompassing type of consolidation — the coming together of providers (hospitals, physicians) with insurers into (closed)...

article_metadata.description: As health care providers and payers consolidate and take advantage of new opportunities brought about by the Affordable Care Act and health care reform, both payers and providers face new health care fraud and abuse and antitrust risks that are different from the ones they previously confronted, say Troy Barsky and Katherine Funk of Crowell & Moring LLP.
